citations.narrative:
The facility maintains computerized acquisition and disposition records instead of APHIS Form 7005 (Record of
Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand) and APHIS Form 7006 (Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats) but does not
have an approved variance.
Utilizing computerized records without a variance does not allow APHIS to review the recordkeeping system prior to its
approval to ensure it is comparable to required forms 7005 and 7006.
Each dealer shall use Record of Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record of Disposition
of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this
section: Provided, that if a dealer who uses a computerized recordkeeping system believes that APHIS Form 7005 and
APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph (a)(1)
of this section, the dealer may request a variance from the requirement to use APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006.
Correct by: August 16, 2023

There was no written contingency plan on file at the facility.
Failure to have a written contingency plan can result in lack of readiness for emergencies or disasters.
Facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment,
transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster.
Correct by: September 13, 2023

The facility provided a verbal plan for exercise for the dogs but does not have written document of the plan to provide
dogs with opportunity for exercise. Without this plan, the facility may not be providing exercise for dogs as required by
paragraph 3.8. It is necessary to allow the dogs the opportunity to exercise for their health and well being. A documented
and approved exercise plan helps ensure that a dogs' space requirements and exercise needs have been considered and
will be provided.
The facility must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In
addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must include written standard procedures to
be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise.
Correct by: August 16, 2023

There was no written program of veterinary care for dogs available for review. The facility has a schedule for vaccination
and veterinary visits but did not have anything documented in writing signed by the veterinarian.
Without an established and written program of veterinary care, USDA cannot assess the level of veterinary care,
prevention, and treatment plans of the dogs in the kennel.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and
signed by the attending veterinarian and must keep and maintain the written program and make it available for APHIS
inspection.
Correct by: August 16, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(2) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility maintains computerized acquisition and disposition records instead of APHIS Form 7005 (Record of 
Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand) and APHIS Form 7006 (Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats) but does not 
have an approved variance. 
Utilizing computerized records without a variance does not allow APHIS to review the recordkeeping system prior to its 
approval to ensure it is comparable to required forms 7005 and 7006. 
Each dealer shall use Record of Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record of Disposition 
of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this 
section: Provided, that if a dealer who uses a computerized recordkeeping system believes that APHIS Form 7005 and 
APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph (a)(1) 
of this section, the dealer may request a variance from the requirement to use APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006.  
Correct by: August 16, 2023 
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
There was no written contingency plan on file at the facility. 
Failure to have a written contingency plan can result in lack of readiness for emergencies or disasters. 
Facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, 
transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. 
Correct by: September 13, 2023 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The facility provided a verbal plan for exercise for the dogs but does not have written document of the plan to provide 
dogs with opportunity for exercise. Without this plan, the facility may not be providing exercise for dogs as required by 
paragraph 3.8. It is necessary to allow the dogs the opportunity to exercise for their health and well being. A documented 
and approved exercise plan helps ensure that a dogs' space requirements and exercise needs have been considered and 
will be provided. 
The facility must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In

addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must include written standard procedures to 
be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise. 
Correct by: August 16, 2023 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There was no written program of veterinary care for dogs available for review. The facility has a schedule for vaccination 
and veterinary visits but did not have anything documented in writing signed by the veterinarian. 
Without an established and written program of veterinary care, USDA cannot assess the level of veterinary care, 
prevention, and treatment plans of the dogs in the kennel. 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and 
signed by the attending veterinarian and must keep and maintain the written program and make it available for APHIS 
inspection. 
Correct by: August 16, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
